text:
The user wants to install Cisco Packet Tracer on Nobara Linux.
Since the previous task was canceled, I need you to quickly find the current best practice for installing Packet Tracer on Fedora-based systems (like Nobara).

Focus on:
1.  Is there a Flatpak wrapper available? (This is usually the easiest).
2.  If not, what are the dependencies needed to run the `.deb` converted to RPM, or is Distrobox preferred?

Provide the instructions so I can add them to `restore_instructions.txt`. Note that the user must download the actual installer themselves due to licensing.

<google:search>
<queries>
<query>Cisco Packet Tracer Flatpak</query>
<query>install Cisco Packet Tracer on Nobara Linux</query>
<query>install Cisco Packet Tracer on Fedora 40</query>
<query>Packet Tracer 8.2.2 Fedora install dependencies</query>
</queries>
</google:search>

<google:search>
<queries>
<query>Cisco Packet Tracer Flatpak Flathub</query>
<query>install Cisco Packet Tracer Fedora 40 Distrobox</query>
<query>Cisco Packet Tracer 8.2.2 Fedora dependencies rpm</query>
</queries>
</google:search>

<google:search>
<queries>
<query>Cisco Packet Tracer Flatpak Flathub</query>
<query>install Cisco Packet Tracer Fedora 40</query>
<query>Packet Tracer 8.2.2 Fedora dependencies</query>
<query>Packet Tracer Distrobox Fedora</query>
</queries>
</google:search>
